comments.text:
+Michael Flohr , you write: "But nonetheless it would be disturbing if 
developed nations cannot hold up a minimal standerd of a flattened out 
tail". Here I disagree. I think that the level of consumption that we 
maintain in the developed nations is so much above the sustainable level 
that it would be disturbing if we insisted on holding that standard.

The reason the so-called "poor" in our "developed" societies are unhappy is 
because they are pressured to participate in our consumption society and 
feel bad that they can't. They are excluded from society because they are 
not winning at the "more" game, to use the language of the video. Move 
anyone from our society into a "developing" society while keeping their 
current income level and they will realise that what they are missing here 
is not more material wealth but a chance to participate in and be respected 
by society. 

Of course I am not proposing to move anyone. I am proposing that our 
society change its values.
comments.author: Gustav Delius

comments.text:
Many thanks for your answer, +Gustav Delius . I see that I phrased my 
statement misleadingly. It is absolutely true that huge numbers of humans 
were and are lifted out of poverty. 

What I am worried about is not the exponential distribution of wealth per 
se. What worries me is that I think (and hopefully, I am mistaken) that the 
evolution of this exponential distribution in developed nations currently 
does not anymore flatten out the tail. I fear that currently more and more 
people in developed nations fall below a certain threshold. It is of course 
true that this is outweighed by the far larger number of people in 
developing and second-world countries, who come out of poverty. But 
nonetheless it would be disturbing if developed nations cannot hold up a 
minimal standerd of a flattened out tail. 

The second thing which worries me is that in very recent history the 
exponential distribution has started to evolve exponentially. That means 
that accumulation of ever larger parts of the global wealth in ever smaller 
numbers of individuals has sped up enormously. This is the exponential 
process I meant where I fear it cannot be stopped or reverted in a 
non-violent way. And I further believe that this accumulation of wealth 
into the hands of a very few cannot be good. Too much then depends on these 
very few human beings having good values and good intentions. We are then 
back at the times of emperors on whose mercifulness the fate of the many 
depends without a way to influence this very much.

The typical argument that the many make the market on which the wealth of 
the few relies may loose its validity when the dominance of the pure 
financial sector becomes overwhelming. 

However, many of the thoughts you shared were very helpful to me and 
convinced me that my point of view might be too pessimistic indeed.
comments.author: Michael Flohr

comments.text:
+Michael Flohr , I don't think the exponential tail in the wealth 
distribution should be changed. I think it is very healthy to have some 
people in control of a larger amount of capital. I am a capitalist in that 
sense. I just want the rich to get their satisfaction not out of using 
their wealth for consumption but from using their wealth to realise 
benefits for society. I want them to get their high status not from how 
much they own but from how much they achieve for society. There are some 
good things that Bill Gates can achieve that individuals with fewer 
financial resources could not. Or a better example: there are some things 
that entrepreneurs like Larry Page and Sergei Brin have achieved that a 
state-run economy could not achieve. It is not how much someone owns that 
is the issue, but what ideals are driving them.

I am however concerned about a cutoff of the distribution at the lower end, 
i.e., I don't want anyone to have less than needed for a happy and healthy 
live. Having rich people around does not hurt (after all, money is just a 
societal construct). The problem is that society currently still associates 
"more" with "better" and thus envy is created when the materially "poor" in 
our society see the materially rich, and thus in the current climate the 
exponential wealth distribution is creating problems for societal cohesion. 
I feel that the stoking of this feeling of envy towards the materially rich 
that some parties engage in for short-term populistic benefit is very 
dangerous and influences society in exactly the wrong direction.

I distinguish between those people that our society brands as "poor" even 
though they have enough material resources to consume above the globally 
sustainable level and the really poor. So I would like to reformulate your 
question from asking for "examples in human history, where exponential 
processes were stopped and changed non-violently and smoothly" to "examples 
in human history where huge numbers of people are pulled out of real 
poverty, thereby flattening the exponential distribution at the lower end". 
Now that has happened in all developed nations, mostly in the 19th and 20th 
century and is happening at a rapid speed in India, China and many other 
developing nations now. Billions are being pulled out of poverty. The only 
thing that could endanger that trend would be if people in the developed 
world not soon stop to overconsume, depleting the globes resources before 
they can be used to lift everyone out of poverty.
comments.author: Gustav Delius

comments.text:
I am glad that you are still optimistic, +Gustav Delius s. And yes, there 
have been examples where society drove changes. 

There is one bit that worries me and which makes me doubt that it will work 
out in this case as well. What worries me is that the current goal "More" 
has led to a redistribution of wealth which is increasingly exponential. I 
would be delighted if you happen to know examples in human history, where 
exponential processes were stopped and changed non-violently and smoothly. 
(Of course, I mean exponential processes with positive exponent.)
comments.author: Michael Flohr

comments.text:
+Michael Flohr , I am much more hopeful than you. I believe that societal 
values can change a lot over time. You and I grew up in a time when making 
a lot of money was highly valued, so we are tempted to think that this is 
the natural state of a society. We have difficulty thinking differently. 
Even your categorisation above was in terms of money. You categorised 
segments of society by how much money they make. I think we need to start 
segmenting differently, not by how much money someone makes but by how they 
lead their lives and by how much they are in a positive feedback loop with 
their community. 

What you say about those that are "poor" is unfortunately true. They are 
held back by thinking of themselves as poor. Unfortunately politicians and 
media are reinforcing this a lot. Let's face it: everyone in Europe, even 
the so-called "poor", are already consuming at a higher level than the 
globe can sustain if everyone in the world achieved the same level of 
consumption.

So it is really important that the "poor" are not told that they need to 
strive to get "richer". Instead everyone should be measured by how close 
their consumption level is to the globally sustainable level. That 
immediately removes the negative image that is currently associated with 
being "poor". And it puts a lot of burden and societal pressure on everyone 
to lower their consumption levels.

This change of view would remove the current culture of envy towards the 
"rich". Instead we would foster what the Germans know as "Reichtum 
verpflichtet". The "rich" would again be expected to make particularly 
strong efforts of giving back to society. 

There are examples that society's views can change. It used to be cool to 
smoke. This was reinforced by a powerful tobacco industry through lobbying 
and through advertising. Now it is no longer cool to smoke. Society's view 
has changed completely.

But it is still cool to consume. This general consumption is of course 
supported by a much more powerful lobby. But I am hopeful nevertheless. 
There are so many reasons to lower consumption. All the effort we currently 
put into consumption we could put into strengthening society, into 
education, into health (mental and physical), into science.

+Lukas Delius , am I unrealistically optimistic? Or can society change as 
much as I hope?
comments.author: Gustav Delius

comments.text:
The public is constantly brainwashed by a huge apparatus to believe that 
increase of GDP is the only way that a more or less comfortable life for 
each of them individually can be sustained. This brainwashing is so strong 
that it even manages to upheld this believe against the fact that an ever 
growing and by now disturbingly high percentage of the populations of most 
high tech nations cannot anymore participate in this comfortable way of 
life. 

Imho, the problem is that our society works like that: 

1) If you are poor, the system will make sure that your influence on it is 
negligible. Since you are socially outcast it is difficult to join other 
poor people to join an alliance which could gain some weight. Most poor 
people I know do everything to appear as "normal", i.e. sufficiently 
financially potent, just to not feel entirely as outcasts. And most of them 
believe, their hopeless situation is their fault, as they are told so 
continuously in many direct and even more indirect ways.

2) If you are "rich" (above a certain level), you almost certainly will 
want to keep it that way. You have a job in a company which goes to quite 
some lengths to educate you to believe that you are a "Leistungsträger" and 
thus better that other people earning less. You deserve to live better and 
to be richer than these others. It's the fault of the poor ones that they 
are poor. You definitely don't want anything which lessens the gap. And 
hence you won't join the side which wants to change the goal from "more" to 
"better". I have experienced that often enough with people I know well. 
This is a real issue. Needless to say that this group is currently the most 
influential in our society.

3) You earn enough, but not much. Then you are either working for a company 
on a lower paid entry level job and are just waiting to reach stage 2, or 
you are one of these rare people like academics working at a university, 
for whom money is not that important. In the first case, you long for 2 
expecting that your career will eventually get you there, and are already 
brainwashed. In the latter case, you probably already know that the society 
and the forces reigning it are giving a damn about you. You can feel lucky 
if society is continuing to provide for you. You can only hope to become 
really famous (win the Noble prize e.g.). In case you become really famous 
you soon find out that you still have almost no influence, if you are 
starting to tell anything against the official point of view.

4) You belong to the top of group 2. Then you almost certainly are a 
psychopath and misanthrop. Your personality is such that in earlier times, 
you would have become a war lord or great warrior, or a king. You believe 
that you are superior to other people, and you believe that this gives you 
rights beyond ordinary rights for everybody, In particular, you believe 
that you do not have to justify your decisions. Fighting and war are the 
natural categories in which you think. The Ackerman "v" is just a harmless 
glitch, the truth is much much worse - in my opinion. As we have seen in 
the last big financial crisis, it is almost impossible to touch these 
people or to let them take responsibility (with real consequences) for 
their doings. 

Don't get me wrong. Such videos are great. There should be a lot more like 
these. However, I have a very bad feeling that this system of pure 
"more"-driven economy cannot be changed peacefully and slowly. I fear we 
all will have to go through some cataclysm before there will be the right 
conditions to change the game. But if there is even the slightest chance 
that the system can evolve non-violently, it surely is worth trying.

It is just my sad personal experience that people, formally my friends, 
which after starting a career in one of the bigger companies or banks, 
changed beyond recognition in their character and their personality, that 
made me write this rant. And I wish to close it with a more hopeful 
statement, namely that I also know people who made (quite a steap) career, 
but remained faithful to themselves and their ideals.
comments.author: Michael Flohr

comments.text:
I very much like the app you outline. In my work I use the following 
approach http://s23m.com/methodology/index.html to value chain/cycle 
engineering. This 5-minute video http://s23m.com/logistics/index.html 
illustrates the essence. The approach can obviously be applied at any 
scale, including at the scale of economic relationships between customers 
and suppliers. Together with my colleagues I am working on software for 
representing the links within concrete local economic subsystems.

I see no real technological obstacle for implementing the suggested app. 
The main stumbling block could be a lack of open data on resource and waste 
*flows*. Remember that waste flows are only required to be tracked to a 
certain extent, and only for materials where relevant and effective 
regulation is in place.

Indeed the educational effect of gaining a better understanding of the 
effects of specific priorities could be the primary benefit of the app. I 
would expect priorities to be readjusted on a frequent basis , leading to 
an economy that becomes much more conscious of undesirable waste flows 
(externalities).
comments.author: Jorn Bettin

comments.text:
Interesting. Perhaps there should be an app for that: Using open government 
data, the app would provide a summary of "progress towards better" tailored 
to the user's local community and personal priorities. The app would also 
allow the user to opt in to feeding back anonymously to government this 
progress towards their personal priorities and those of their local 
community. That would provide valuable information for shaping government 
policy. Furthermore, that feedback could be aggregated into a single metric 
that could replace GDP. Do you think that metric might provide a useful and 
beneficial way to measure a government's success?

Perhaps the measurement of "progress towards better" will not be the most 
important benefit of such an app. Instead the educational effect that 
choosing their own priority settings in the app will have might be 
substantial.

I wonder, is the creation of such an app perhaps feasible already with 
currently available open data? And if it is, would a representative 
cross-section of the population adopt it? Or would it just again give even 
greater influence to the digitally savy? But, given the widespread adoption 
of smartphones, and the appetite of the public for personalised 
information, I don't think the idea is altogether unpromising.

Perhaps this idea is not new? Perhaps there is already an app for that? I 
would really like to try it.
comments.author: Gustav Delius

comments.text:
I am not opposed to metrics for *better*. I am simply pointing out the need 
for *many* metrics for *better*, and not a simplistic universal one. For 
example a dedicated metric for measuring *better* health is desirable, as 
well as dedicated metrics for measuring *less* chemical externalities in 
production, transport, and agriculture, etc. The priorities that different 
local communities will attach to the various metrics heavily depend on the 
local context, specifically on the means that are (or are not) available 
locally to address  economic externalities, and on the local severity of 
the effects of different kinds of externalities.
comments.author: Jorn Bettin

comments.text:
+Jorn Bettin , I agree with most of what you say. However I am not so sure 
that efforts to define a new metric for "better" should be avoided. Clearly 
the public, the media and the politicians want a metric to measure success, 
otherwise growth in GDP would not play such a big role. It seems the most 
realistic way to displace that misguided use of GDP is to advocate the use 
of an alternative, all the while of course continuing to warn of the 
inherent danger of any single metric.
comments.author: Gustav Delius

comments.text:
We need many more such videos and explanations to raise public awareness.

The challenge starts with the vocabulary we use to talk about economics, 
and the semantics that have been built into the economic vocabulary over 
the last century (winning = more, wealth = financial assets, human nature = 
striving for personal gain, etc.), which makes it very hard for people to 
articulate alternatives without being misunderstood.

Videos and illustrations can help overcome this difficulty.

Beyond the challenge of language, there is also the real danger of 
inventing "alternative" systems that are simply reincarnations of the old 
system in a new package. For example any system that attempts to define a 
universal metric for "better" will run into the same old issues. Currencies 
such as Bitcoin that are designed for universal use are concrete examples 
of misguided alternatives.

There is a need for domain-specific metrics, to track flows of all the 
different categories of resources and externalities. Only then can we begin 
to systematically think about the construction of waste-free value cycles.
comments.author: Jorn Bettin

comments.text:
I don't exactly appreciate the fact that you assumed I've only spent 
several minutes studding the tragedy of the commons, but your article has 
explained exactly why I have only been exposed this type of thinking:
 "Hardin’s misrepresentation of the commons became a familiar catchphrase, 
and the “tragedy” syndrome went on to become a much-taught concept in 
undergraduate education. In the meantime, contemporary economic theory has 
ignored actual working commons."

I enjoyed the article though, it was well thought out. I think much of the 
confusion between your views and mine can be attributed to the fact that we 
define the commons as two completely different things as explained in the 
article:
" Hardin was not describing a commons, but rather an open access regime or 
free-for-all in which everything is free for the taking without constraint. 
In a commons, however, there is a distinct community of users who govern 
the resource. The commoners negotiate their own rules of usage, assign 
responsibilities and entitlements, and set up monitoring systems and 
penalties to identify free riders, among other acts to maintain the 
commons." 

But that being said, I still disagree with the feasibility of the commons 
as described in the article. I believe there are far too many idealistic 
properties that must be met in order for the commons paradigm to work. Many 
of these limitations are nearly impossible to oust with the exception of 
the internet. Here's a few Bollier talks about in the article:
"Inappropriate or ineffectual governance, bad leadership, and ill-advised 
group consensus can all damage the effective working of the commons, and 
commoners may have disagreements and conflicts that cannot always be 
bridged..."

The big exception is indeed the internet. Wikipedia is the example I liked 
the best. Wikipedia CAN work as a commons because any changes to its 
contents can be monitored. But the Internet is not a good representation of 
real life scenarios; I believe corruption and conflict keep away any hopes 
of this idealistic version of the commons from ever becoming reality.

comments.text:
+Jacob
The answer to your convoluted question is "All of the most basic and 
fundamental principles of economics 101".

In a free market, competition prevents prices from going above what the 
market can bear. If merchant A jacks up his prices, this creates an 
opportunity for merchant B to take market share away from A. If A and B 
collude and bring up both of their prices at the same time, this creates an 
opportunity for merchant C to enter the market as an entrepreneur and take 
market share away from both of them. Competition always leads to the lowest 
possible price for consumers.

Something you've failed to realize in your question is that LABOR is just 
one of many services offered in the free market. If A offers $2 per hour, 
and B is offering $3 per hour, employees will leave A to go to B for the 
better wage. A will see his workers fleeing for higher wages and offer a 
competitive wage to retain them. B, however wants to keep the very best 
workers for himself, so he offers $4 to retain them. Wash, rinse, repeat. 
Competition for labor always leads to the highest possible wage for the job 
in question. What is the highest possible wage? It's how ever much you can 
afford to pay in labor, and still earn the desired profit margin off of the 
work the employee performs. If the job requires very little skill and 
labor, the highest wage will be very low because a one armed monkey could 
do it. However, if the job requires skill and a strong work ethic, the 
price of labor goes way up because not only does the employer have to 
attract someone who can do the job, he wants to retain the workers who will 
do the job the best.

Slavery is only possible under a strong government which will enforce the 
right of slave holders to keep slaves. Brazil, for example, never abolished 
slavery, but there are none now. Why? Because rather than abolishing it, 
the government simply stopped helping retrieve run away slaves. When the 
cost of keeping the slaves grew to be more than the value of having slaves, 
people simply stopped using slaves. It was cheaper just to pay them a 
voluntary wage.

top_comment.text:
Can't wait for Lee Doren to tear this one to shreds. Lots of talking with 
no substance in this one. I would just like to point out that plastic bags 
are extremely cost effective, banning them just drives the price of goods 
higher as paper bags are expensive by comparison. And reusable bags are a 
scam. And are frequently made from synthetic fibers that are made from 
recycled plastic bags. Also the little piece called "financial speculation 
tax"... Yeah that's a bad idea. Google it, if you cant figure it out on 
your own, send me 1% of all transactions you make. If you give to charity, 
or buy groceries, send me 1%, you will figure it out soon enough.﻿
top_comment.author: AhKeelU

comments.text:
So, you paid for the bags, which you then use to shop with. Bags which you 
didn't need because you could have gotten plastic bags and reused. All 
because its "green" creating a false sense of a need for plastic bags which 
are used by many for uses far beyond groceries. I define that as a scam, 
convincing someone they NEED something that they in fact do not. In many 
African countries that gets sent trash (I disapprove of this practice) 
plastic bags are used for condoms and the estimate of the impact on the 
aids epidemic is notable. They are a poor substitute but save many lives. 
Others make rope out of them. And they are always recyclable. So yes, they 
are a scam and "ban the bag" causes more issues than it helps.

captions.text:
The Story of Solutions (Why making real
change starts with changing the game)
with Annie Leonard

Do you have one of these, of course
not this thing is five years old
now everyone's got on of these.

Can you imagine how much genius and focus
it took to turn a music player into

a hand-held computer, phone, GPS, remote control
for everything in life in just five years.
Seriously

The thousands of people who made this
thing had to solve thousands of problems

that literally could not have
been solved five years ago.

That's what people can do when they are
motivated to find solutions to problems.

But the problems we've been busy solving are
not the problems that most need solving.

So much focus has gone into
faster, cheaper, newer.

That we've actually lost ground on things
like safer, healthier and more fair.

It is as if we are getting better and
better at playing the wrong game.

And, in many ways this system is a lot
like a game, but with very high stakes.
Just like a game

our economy was designed by people to
get everyone to play by certain rules

and, like a game, it comes with
instructions telling us what the goal is.

Think about the last time
you played a new game
Remember ?

The first thing you did was
find out what it means to win

and that guides every decision
you make along the way.

So naturally the solutions most people are
working on pursue this games simple goal
and that goal is more.

More money being spent, more roads being
built, more malls being opened, more stuff.

That's what economists
call growth.

So we take all the money spent
on stuff that makes life better

and all the money spent on
stuff that makes life worse

and we add it together
into one big number
called GDP.

Were told that a bigger
GDP means we're winning

So it's the number that thousands of the
rules and laws are designed to increase.

But there's a big difference between more
kids in school or more kids in jail.

More windmills or
more coal-fired power plants.

More super-efficient public trains
or more gas wasted in traffic jams.

But in this game of more
they are counted same.

Now we can't change a game this dumb
one rule or one player at time.

The problem is the goal itself. 
We need solutions that change that.

What if we built this game
around goal of better.

Better education, better health, 
better stuff.

A better chance to
survive on this planet.
That's what we all want. right?

So shouldn't that be
what winning means?

Changing the goal of the
entire economy is a huge task.

Of course we can't
do it all at once.

But when we focus on
game-changing solutions

we gradually make it possible
for a new game to be played.

To do that we have to be able to tell the
difference between a game-changing solution

or just a new way to play
that old game of more.
For example,

let's look at two solutions to one
of the many problems we face today.

The scourge of plastic packaging that
everyone knows is a disaster for the planet.
Especially the oceans.
And, here are two groups of people

with very different ideas of
solutions to the plastics' problem.

These guys decide
that enough is enough

and they start by launching a citizen campaign
to ban the plastic bag in their community.

these guys have a
different solution.
They start a business

that gives people's gift cards to buy
stuff if they recycle their plastic waste.

Both of these are
happening right now,

but only one if them
changes the game.

The gift card solution does keep some
plastic out of landfills and incinerators.

But it creates more plastic by
encouraging people to buy more stuff.
Even worse,

it teaches that more consumption is the
right reward for being a good citizen.

Making it even harder to think
outside that old game box.

The 'ban the bag' solution
is harder to achieve,
but it's a game-changer.
Why?

Well, by volunteering their time,
these citizens are declaring that

there's something more important to them
than just earning and spending more.

To win this campaign, these citizens
are gonna have to team up with

forward-thinking businesses offering
alternatives to throw away plastic packaging.

They're gonna have to build power to fight
back against the American Chemistry Council.

Which is lobbies for the company’s
that make all that plastic junk.

And they're gonna have to get out and
talk to their neighbors and friends

inspiring yet more people to
begin to question the old game.

This is exactly what's happening in
towns and cities all across the world
and they're winning.

But can banning a few million plastic
bags transform the goal of the game.
By itself no,

but in combination with
millions of others working on

game-changing solutions
that they care about,
YES.

Together these solutions are
beginning to turn the tide.

As people build power
to change the game
their citizen muscles grow.

They work to ensure the local solutions
they create get copied and scaled up.

And when they see the solutions getting blocked
by corporations with way too much influence

they team up with other solutionaries
to fight for a real democracy
by the people, for the people.
Gift cards will never do that

but thousands off citizen
campaigns can.

Whenever I'm asked to join in a solution
I want to know if it's transformational
will it change the goal?

To figure it out I
use the word GOAL

I want to know that it G-
gives people more power

taking power back from
corporations to build democracy.

O - opens people's eyes to the truth
that once basic needs are met

happiness and well-being don't
come from buying more stuff

but from our communities, our
health and a sense of purpose.

A - accounts for all
the cost it creates

including the toll it takes
on people and the planet

In other words it internalizes
costs instead of externalizing them
as most businesses do today.

L - lessens the enormous wealth gap between
those who can't even meet the basic needs

and those who consume way
more than their fair share.

When I see solution that does all
that or can be redesigned to
I'm in.

And they're popping
up everywhere.

Like the Evergreen
cooperatives in Cleveland.

Where worker owners are
running green businesses.

A laundry, a solar company and
a super productive urban farm
that are healthy and safe.

They provide secure jobs to people
that the old game has left behind.

We all know we need to get
businesses out of our democracy.

But cooperatives go even further and bring
democracy into the businesses.

Sustainable,
democratic, equitable.
That's a game-changer.

Or in Capennori, a town in Italy where local
citizens working with businesses and governments

are not just seeking
to manage waste better

but they're questioning the
very inevitability of waste.

They're promoting solutions to waste
not with expensive techno fixes

but by working together as a community
to reclaim compost for the soil,

to find reusable substitutes
for disposable products

and then to put discarded
material to good use.

They've already reduce some
waste streams by 82 percent

while creating jobs and
building social fabric.

And how about the new trend
of collaborative consumption
formerly known as 'sharing'.

Sharing may sound like
the theme of Barney song

but think about it, it's a
huge challenge to the old game.

It gets as off the treadmill
of 'More-More-More',

conserves resources, gives people access
to stuff they otherwise couldn't afford
and builds communities.
what does it look like?

Bike share programs
in major cities,

online platforms that let us share everything
from our cars to our homes to camping gear.

In my town the public library
system lends out tools.

There's just no reason that every
house needs its own power drill,

crème brûlée torch, scanner, wheelbarrow,
a bike pump, when we can share.

As transformational solutions
like these gain traction

we will reach a tipping point. If we
keep focused on the new goal of better.

Without a new goal all the work we're
doing to build a better future will be
A) not enough and B) really hard.

Too much genius and focus will continue to go
to solving problems like iPhone battery life

while the problems that threaten
human life spin out of control.

Five years ago when we
made the story of stuff

we started building a community of people who sensed
that something was really wrong with this old game.
We agreed there was a problem.

Now it's time to
build the solutions.

Solutions that won't just change a few of
the rules but will change the entire game.
Wanna help?
Come on let's do it.
